title: Key documents you need in Switzerland
subtitle: What to keep in one folder and where to get each paper
bodyMarkdown:
# Essential documents in Switzerland

After arrival, you should quickly assemble a basic document set. You will need it for registration, insurance, school, work and the bank.

## Core documents
- Passport or ID card for all family members
- Residence permit (Ausweis S/B/C)
- Registration confirmation from the Gemeinde (Anmeldebestätigung)
- Health insurance policy
- Rental contract (Mietvertrag)

## Where to get what
- **Gemeinde / Einwohnerkontrolle** – registration at your address, confirmations of residence
- **Migrationsamt** – residence permit questions
- **Krankenkasse** – medical insurance
- **AHV / Sozialamt** – social benefits and subsidies

Keep scans of all documents in a secure cloud folder and never send originals by post unless explicitly required.

title: Finding a flat in Switzerland
subtitle: Homegate, ImmoScout24, WG rooms and the rental dossier
bodyMarkdown:
# How to search for housing

The Swiss rental market is very competitive. Good flats can get dozens of applications within a day.

## Where to look
- **homegate.ch** – biggest real‑estate portal
- **immoscout24.ch** – strong alternative
- **tutti.ch** – private ads, often less competition
- **wgzimmer.ch** – shared flats (WG rooms)

## Your application dossier
- Copy of passport and residence permit
- Employment contract or proof of income
- Last three salary slips (if available)
- Debt‑register extract (Betreibungsauszug)

Prepare everything as PDFs so you can send a complete application within minutes after a viewing.

title: Health insurance basics
subtitle: Franchise, HMO/Telmed models and premium subsidies
bodyMarkdown:
# Choosing health insurance

Basic health insurance is mandatory for everyone who lives in Switzerland. You must sign up within three months after registration.

Compare offers on **comparis.ch** or **bonus.ch**, pick a franchise you can really afford, and check whether you qualify for premium subsidies (Prämienverbilligung) in your canton.

title: Working in Switzerland: where to start
subtitle: Job portals, Swiss‑style CV and what HR expects
bodyMarkdown:
# First steps on the Swiss job market

Use **jobs.ch**, **jobup.ch**, **indeed.ch** and **job-room.ch** to search. Keep your CV to 1–2 pages, with clear structure and real achievements. Always adapt your cover letter to each vacancy.

title: Managing your budget in Switzerland
subtitle: Typical monthly costs, taxes and where to get help
bodyMarkdown:
# Personal finances for newcomers

Rent, insurance and transport are the biggest expenses. Use tools like **budgetberatung.ch** for example budgets and always keep some buffer for yearly bills (taxes, insurances).

title: School system for children
subtitle: Kindergarten, primary and lower‑secondary school explained
bodyMarkdown:
# Education for children

Compulsory schooling usually runs from age 4–6 to 15. After you register at the Gemeinde, the school authority (Schulamt) will assign a school and send you a letter with all details.

title: Seeing a doctor in Switzerland
subtitle: Family doctors, emergencies and walk‑in clinics
bodyMarkdown:
# How the healthcare system works

Choose a family doctor (Hausarzt) near your home and keep their number handy. For real emergencies call **144** or go to a Notfall. For minor acute issues many cities offer Permanence / walk‑in clinics.

title: Free legal support for refugees
subtitle: Where to find advice before signing any contract
bodyMarkdown:
# Legal help

Organisations like Caritas, HEKS, the Red Cross and university legal clinics often provide free or low‑cost consultations. Never sign a contract you do not understand – ask for a translation or legal check first.

title: Emergency numbers and what to say
subtitle: 144, 117, 118 and psychological hotlines
bodyMarkdown:
# Emergencies in Switzerland

Main numbers are **144** (ambulance), **117** (police), **118** (fire brigade), **143** (emotional support) and **145** (poison control). Teach children your address and name so they can call if needed.

title: Integration: language courses and community hubs
subtitle: How to build a network in your canton
bodyMarkdown:
# Integration tips

Check your Gemeinde or city website for subsidised language courses and integration programmes. Ukrainian hubs and community centres (see map in Sweezy) are great places to meet people, share experience and get practical help.

title: Public transport and travel passes
subtitle: Halbtax, GA and regional passes explained
bodyMarkdown:
# Saving money on transport

Halbtax gives you 50% off most tickets; GA offers unlimited travel. If you mostly stay in one region, a regional pass like ZVV or Unireso may be cheaper.

title: Bank accounts and sending money home
subtitle: Which bank to choose and how to avoid high fees
bodyMarkdown:
# Banking basics

PostFinance and major banks like UBS or Raiffeisen are common choices. For cheaper international transfers to Ukraine, services like Wise or Revolut often beat classic SWIFT transfers.
